This explains the words of the Midrash presented at the beginning of our discussion: It is written "Deep waters are counsel in the heart of man." This is comparable to a deep well filled with cold water, etc. Someone came and tied rope to rope and thread to thread, etc. The meaning of this mashal (parable) according to our approach is that the depths of Lashon Hakodesh (the Holy Tongue), according to its spiritual root above in terms of the Divine Presence's manifestation, was hidden in the heart of this man - Joseph, and he didn't reveal it to them until now.

This is what is meant by "no creature was able to drink from it." One came and tied rope to rope and thread to thread, string to string, etc. - this alludes to the chain of descent of the language that descended from the Supreme Merkavah (Divine Chariot) through thousands and tens of thousands of levels, as explained in the aforementioned words of the Shelah HaKadosh.

Thus Judah responded to Joseph word for word until he understood his heart - meaning that he revealed to him the knowledge of the language that until now was hidden in his heart. Similarly, this explains the words of the Midrash: "Golden apples in silver settings, a word spoken in its proper way." Just as a wheel shows faces to every side, so too were Judah's words apparent from every angle when he spoke with Joseph.

According to our approach, he spoke to him in Lashon Hakodesh according to its root above, and the inner dimension of Lashon Hakodesh in its highest aspect is unfathomable, as you find in the language of the Holy Torah - gematriot (numerical values), letter substitutions, and endless allusions. This is what is meant by "just as a wheel shows faces to every side, so too were Judah's words apparent from every angle when he spoke with Joseph" - through the aspect of Lashon Hakodesh that he spoke to him, and through this he understood his heart, understand this.

In this way, it can be explained regarding Yosef HaTzaddik that when he revealed himself to his brothers, he spoke to them in Lashon HaKodesh (the Holy Tongue) according to his spiritual root above, in the same language that the Holy One Blessed be He gave the Torah to His people Israel. Due to the great holiness of the tribes and the great holiness of those words, the Divine Presence (Shechinah) came to rest upon him, and the Shechinah spoke through his throat. They could see the voices with their physical sense of sight, and this was clear proof that he was indeed Yosef HaTzaddik, for it would be impossible for any other person in Egypt to merit such a level where the Shechinah would speak through his throat and his speech would be perceived through the sense of sight.

This is what is meant by "for your eyes see that it is my mouth speaking to you." Such a level of speech and such a quality of Lashon HaKodesh could not possibly exist among the people from across the river or the Canaanites. This serves as definitive proof that "I am Yosef." Such speech, where the heard becomes visible, is only possible in Lashon HaKodesh.

Although our Sages said that every utterance that came from the Holy One Blessed be He at Mount Sinai was divided into seventy languages, it's possible that those portions that were clothed in other languages did not maintain the level of Hashem's speech to be perceived through sight. Letters and words from the seventy languages that can combine to form falsehood and impurity cannot possibly have the Divine Presence rest upon them or contain the aspect of Torah, for with the letters of the Torah, the Holy One Blessed be He created His world, heaven and earth, and countless worlds. All this was through the aspect of Lashon HaKodesh within it.

Similarly, the phenomenon of "seeing the voices" only occurred through the aspect of Lashon HaKodesh within it, and not through what was clothed in the seventy languages. Therefore, Rashi explains "for my mouth speaks to you" refers to Lashon HaKodesh, and "your eyes see" refers to the visible aspect of the speech, which serves as complete proof and verification that "I am Yosef your brother."

However, the explanation of the matter is that if Hashem's intention was only to rectify their encampment places, the journey from place to place could have been accomplished through kefitzat haderech (miraculous shortening of the way) or through the clouds. The Holy One, Blessed be He, would not have troubled them with the journey through the great and awesome desert, for in any case, the journey was miraculous and assisted by the clouds, as our Sages said. If so, the entire journey could have been through the clouds.

But the will and necessity was to rectify and elevate the holy sparks (nitzotzot hakdoshim) along their entire journey route, and the journey itself was an important divine service in its own right. Therefore, it was necessary for their journey to be by foot through the desert path, for if it had been through kefitzat haderech and skipping, they would not have passed through all these places, and the holy sparks there would not have been rectified and elevated.

Therefore, the verse states "they journeyed and encamped" at each journey, and it wasn't sufficient to mention only the encampments, because the journey itself was also a divine service and purpose of rectification just like the encampments. From this, we can explain as Ibn Ezra wrote that when it says "Moses wrote their goings forth according to their journeys by the command of Hashem," it teaches that their journeys were by Hashem's command. This resolves Ramban's question about the redundancy with the earlier verse "by Hashem's command they would camp and by Hashem's command they would journey."

For one might still think that the main purpose was the encampments, and after their encampment place was rectified and they needed another encampment, their journey was by Hashem's command, but the journey was secondary and merely a means to the purpose of the encampments. Therefore, the verse repeats to say "according to their journeys by the command of Hashem," without mentioning the encampments in this verse, to teach that the journeys themselves were an important divine service and by Hashem's command.

Now when he made himself known to his brothers and said to them "I am Yosef, is my father still alive, etc." His brothers could have been puzzled and doubted the truthfulness of his words, for if his words were true, how could he have endured his father's pain for so many years without informing him, especially since he had the ability to do so as he was king and ruler, and who could question his actions? Based on this, we can understand the words of the Midrash that we began with "And Judah approached him." "Deep waters are counsel in the heart of man, etc." - This is comparable to a deep well, etc. Thus Judah did not move, etc. until he understood his heart. The meaning of the mashal (parable) that compares Joseph's words to deep waters is because the matters of redemption (geulah) that were hinted at in his words were very deep and impossible to fully comprehend their secret (sod), and the heart does not reveal to the mouth. Then one came and tied rope to rope, thread to thread, etc. Similarly, Judah did not cease responding word for word until he understood his heart, meaning that through his words he understood the secret of redemption that was hidden within them at the level of thought in the heart. This is the meaning of "understood his heart" - contemplate this.

The continuation of the mashal can also be understood, which states that one person came and drew from it and drank, and then everyone began drawing from it and drinking. This alludes to the tribes, who also understood the hint of the thought and the secret of redemption. Once the understanding descended from the world of thought through Judah, they too were able to grasp it, and this is the meaning of "everyone began drawing from it."

The Or HaChama in his commentary on the Zohar wrote some explanation on this matter. The essence of his words is that these two types of wagons allude to two aspects, through which Joseph hinted about the exile and redemption until the end of all generations. That is, Joseph's wagons allude to the time of exile, and wagons are vessels of exile, just as these wagons were used when they went into Egyptian exile. Pharaoh's wagons allude to and serve as a symbolic act regarding the future days of redemption, when the nations of the world will bring the Children of Israel from their lands of exile - "those lost in the land of Assyria and those dispersed in the land of Egypt" - as an offering to Hashem with chariots and mules. This is why the Zohar concludes "when they leave from exile, 'and they shall bring all your brethren as an offering to Hashem,'" for this is alluded to in Pharaoh's wagons - that the nations of the world will bring Israel in their wagons as an offering to Hashem, as explained in the verse.

The Shevivei Nogah wrote that the Zohar disagrees with the opinion in the Midrash which states that those wagons of Pharaoh had idolatrous images engraved on them and Judah stood up and burned them. According to the Zohar's view, this is not so; rather, both these and those [wagons] came to Jacob. One can further explain the verse "for you are like Pharaoh" as follows: The holy tribes (Shevatim) prepared through their holy words a prayer and symbolic action for future generations in exile. In every generation, enemies rise up to destroy us, but the Holy One, Blessed be He, saves us from their hands. Through His abundant mercy and kindness, may His name be blessed, He nullifies our enemies' counsel and cancels all harsh decrees against Israel, just as He nullified Pharaoh's decree.

As mentioned in the Gemara (Sotah 12b), Moses was the first to be cast into the Nile. Immediately, the decree was nullified when Pharaoh's astrologers said, "Israel's savior has already been struck," and afterward Moses was saved. Thus, his decree was completely nullified. This is what Yehudah said to Yosef: "You wish to impose a harsh decree upon us from your evil free will. For the holy Patriarchs and tribes saw through their divine inspiration (ruach hakodesh) everything that would happen until the end of generations, except for what was deliberately concealed from Heaven for a specific purpose, such as their inability to recognize Yosef. Similarly, it was concealed from our father Abraham, peace be upon him, during the Akeidah that it wasn't Hashem's will to actually slaughter Yitzchak.

But besides these exceptions, they perceived and saw all future events. Therefore, Yehudah said to Yosef, "for you are like Pharaoh." Just as Pharaoh decrees but doesn't fulfill, as Hashem will nullify his counsel and decree, so too you decree but won't fulfill, and your decree won't stand because the Holy One, Blessed be He, will nullify it.

He further alluded that in every generation, decree-makers would rise against Israel, but Hashem would thwart our enemies' counsel and all would be nullified. This is the meaning of "for you are like Pharaoh" - that people like you and Pharaoh will continue to rise against Israel and issue evil decrees against us, but the Holy One, Blessed be He, will save us from their hands and their decrees will be nullified.

Similarly, in this way, the holy tribes recognized from the angels that were created through Yosef's speech that it was all truth and his mouth matched his heart. This is why he said to them "Behold, your eyes see, and the eyes of my brother Binyamin... that it is my mouth speaking to you," for they could see with their eyes Yosef's words, meaning those angels that were created from his speech. From this they discerned that he spoke truth and his mouth matched his heart, and there was no aspect of falsehood or deception in his words, for if there were, it would have been evident in the angels created from his speech.

He showed them the angels that were created from his mitzvah of milah and that he guarded his covenant, for one who damages his covenant, his foreskin extends. They discerned to know that the mitzvah was complete with him through seeing the holy angels created from his mitzvah of milah.

From this it was clarified to them that he was Yosef HaTzaddik, for such a reality doesn't exist among other people who are not from the seed of Yaakov Avinu, to have the mitzvah of milah in such completeness. It was completely verified to them that he was Yosef, and for this reason the verse repeats to say again "no man stood with him when Yosef made himself known to his brothers," hinting that only man did not stand with him, but those holy angels that were created from his actions and speech of Yosef HaTzaddik stood there.

From them it was verified to the holy tribes that Yosef was their brother, similar to what is written in Yalkut Reuveni (Parshat Vayeshev) that when the attribute of judgment prosecuted the tribes for the sin of selling Yosef, based on what is written "and one who steals a man and sells him, and he is found in his possession, shall surely be put to death," the Holy One Blessed be He responded that it says "steals a man," but Yosef was not a man but rather on the level of an angel. And in this way, the verse hints here "no man stood with him when Yosef made himself known to his brothers," but angels stood there, and through this it was verified to the tribes that he was their brother.

And certainly, one who stumbles even slightly in matters of avodah zarah cannot merit the hashra'as haShechinah.

Therefore, they said "with whomever of your servants it is found, he shall die," meaning his life force would be cut off and the hashra'as haShechinah, which is called "life," would depart from him. Our father Yaakov, peace be upon him, sent Yehudah ahead of him to prepare the way to Goshen, and to establish a Beis Medrash (house of study) as our Sages said. Seemingly, Yosef himself could have prepared this, or it could have been done through any of the other tribes, so why did he send Yehudah who was king?

It appears to be explained based on the Midrash regarding "and he saw the wagons that Yosef sent" - where were the wagons that Pharaoh sent? It teaches that those wagons that Pharaoh sent to carry him had idolatrous images engraved on them, so Yehudah stood up and burned them. This tribe was accustomed to burning avodah zarah (idolatry). The Yefeh Toar and Nitzotzei Kedushah questioned why Yosef didn't burn them himself, and they answered that since Yehudah was especially suited for this task, it was left to him. The Nitzotzei Kedushah elaborates based on the Midrash that "we are not as expert in the details of avodah zarah as our father Yaakov," and similarly, Yehudah was expert in the details of avodah zarah.

Therefore, Yaakov sent Yehudah because he could recognize and discern even hidden aspects of avodah zarah, including thoughts of idolatry, as that tribe was accustomed to burning avodah zarah. Since Yaakov wanted to establish a house from which Torah instruction would emanate, it required careful discrimination to ensure there would be no trace of avodah zarah, and only Yehudah was suited for this as mentioned above. Therefore, he specifically sent Yehudah to prepare the Beis Medrash, ensuring it would be completely free of any trace of avodah zarah, and from there Torah instruction would emerge.

From this, we can see how carefully one must guard against the ways of avodah zarah, requiring extra wisdom to understand, distinguish, and separate from them. This connects to the halachah they taught: "When do we make the blessing over fire at the conclusion of Shabbos? Our rabbis taught that we don't make the blessing until we can benefit from its light." This is because extra recognition is needed to make distinctions, and where did they learn this from? From the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it says, "And God saw the light that it was good" and afterward "God separated between the light and the darkness." For this reason, he sent Yehudah ahead, because extra discernment was needed to prepare a Beis Medrash that would be suitable and worthy for Torah instruction to emanate from it.

One can explain the verse "Your eyes see... for it is my mouth speaking to you," which Chazal interpret as "as my mouth is, so is my heart." In the previous verse it states "I will sustain you there... for there are yet five years of famine, lest you come to poverty, you, and your household, and all that you have." However, seemingly Yosef's promise to feed and sustain them for five more years wasn't fulfilled, as Chazal say that when Yaakov Avinu came to Egypt, the famine immediately ceased in his merit.

It's possible that Yosef knew through Ruach HaKodesh (Divine inspiration) that the famine would end with Yaakov's arrival, as Chazal say in Pirkei D'Rabbi Eliezer that Ruach HaKodesh guided him from his youth until his death. If so, why did he say "I will sustain you... for five more years of famine" when his vow wasn't fulfilled?

However, we have a principle that one shouldn't rely on miracles. Therefore, Yosef HaTzaddik empathized with their suffering and took upon himself wholeheartedly to feed and sustain them for five years. For this, he already received reward for all five years even though the famine ended earlier, as explained in the aforementioned Sifri that one receives reward for the declaration even if unable to complete the action.

So his brothers wouldn't question how he was permitted to make such a vow, since it's forbidden to make vows except by saying "Harei Zu" (behold this is), we explained earlier that it's permitted with proper intention. Therefore, he immediately said "Your eyes see... my mouth speaking to you," which Chazal interpret as "as my mouth is, so is my heart" - meaning his thoughts and intentions were proper, and in such a case it's a mitzvah to make a vow and one receives reward for the declaration as if for the action.

There are those who think that maintaining a large institution with great expenses through limited means and a small number of God-fearing supporters is anyway miraculous, and therefore rely on miracles, thinking they don't need to take action as the miracle will come regardless. But this isn't correct, as we don't rely on miracles. Only through the power of Jews giving with self-sacrifice and proper intention can we exist beyond natural means.

It can be explained by first considering the words of the holy Zohar (beginning of Parshat Vayigash): "And Judah approached him, etc. Rabbi Elazar began... Come and see, when the Holy One, Blessed be He, created the world, etc. When the sixth day came and it was necessary to create man, the Torah came before Him and said: 'This man that You wish to create will anger You in the future. If You will not be patient with his anger, it would be better if he were not created.' The Holy One, Blessed be He, replied: 'Am I called Long-Suffering (Erech Apayim) for nothing?'"

At first glance, we need to understand the connection between this teaching and the verse "And Judah approached him." This can be explained according to the Gemara (Rosh Hashanah 17b) which teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, wrapped Himself like a prayer leader and showed Moses the order of prayer, saying: "Whenever Israel sins, let them perform before Me in this order, and I will forgive them."

The early authorities investigated whether merely reciting the Thirteen Attributes of Mercy is sufficient, or if one must actually embody these attributes in practice, as it is said "Cleave to His attributes - just as He is merciful, etc." In any case, it certainly helps, as the Midrash states "Hashem is your shadow" - meaning that the Holy One, Blessed be He, deals with man as a shadow, and with the measure one uses, they are measured.

The Midrash relates that at that moment, Judah tried to draw his sword from its sheath but could not. Judah said, "Surely this one (Joseph) fears Heaven." Perhaps Judah thought that the reason Joseph wasn't immediately punished (as Pharaoh was regarding Sarah our mother) was because he had merits and the Holy One, Blessed be He, was being patient with him. Therefore, he said to him "for you are like Pharaoh" with two comparative "kafs" - meaning that if another person would act as you do, they would be punished immediately like Pharaoh, but because you have fear of Heaven, the Holy One, Blessed be He, is patient with you, though you will ultimately be punished if you don't return him (Benjamin).

This is what is meant by "let not your anger burn" - although it would be appropriate for your anger to burn, conduct yourself with the attribute of patience, and then the Holy One, Blessed be He, will treat you with this same attribute. He gave the reason "for you are like Pharaoh" - that you deserve to be punished immediately like Pharaoh, but the Holy One, Blessed be He, is patient, and this is only if you too conduct yourself with this attribute.

According to the second interpretation, he said: "If you provoke me, I will kill you..." Because in truth, you deserve to be punished immediately for this act of theft, but the Holy One, Blessed be He, is patient with you. However, if you provoke me and don't conduct yourself with patience, then your punishment will come immediately and I will kill you and your master, and you won't be protected from Heaven to prevent your death.

This explains the connection between the words of the holy Zohar mentioned above and the words of the parsha, as this aspect explained in the Zohar was Judah's argument to Joseph. Understand this.

This explains the Midrash that when Yaakov saw the wagons that Yosef sent, he said, "Now I know for certain that Yosef did not sin with Potiphar's wife." Our Sages of blessed memory said in the Midrash that no one could take wagons out of Egypt without Pharaoh's permission. Even those wagons that Yosef sent needed to be with Pharaoh's permission. Therefore, Pharaoh needed to say to Yosef "you have commanded by my word," to tell them that it was with his permission. For if they didn't tell our father Yaakov that they were sent with Pharaoh's permission, our father Yaakov would not agree to use the wagons, even for their wives and children, as this would constitute rebellion against the kingdom. Thus, even though Yehudah burned Pharaoh's wagons in their place and they never reached Yaakov, nevertheless the Torah later mentions "and the children of Israel carried... their children and their wives in the wagons that Pharaoh sent," since it had to be with Pharaoh's permission, it was as if Pharaoh had sent them. And when they came to their father Yaakov with the wagons that Yosef sent, he saw that they were completely free from any trace of avodah zarah (idolatry). He understood this was from the power of Yosef HaTzaddik, for it is explained in the aforementioned Midrash that no other person was as expert in the minutiae of avodah zarah as Yaakov Avinu, and Yosef learned from him, as Yaakov Avinu transmitted all his wisdom to him, as our Sages said. Abaye said the lender transgresses all [prohibitions], etc., while the guarantor and witnesses only transgress "you shall not place upon him interest."

The Gemara [62a] asks: While all others perform an action, what action do the witnesses perform? Rather, is it not that the very act of establishing [the loan] is significant? Similarly, in our matter, Yosef HaTzaddik preceded going to Egypt to prepare a place for Bnei Yisrael so they could maintain their kedushah (holiness) in Egyptian exile, which was the ervat ha'aretz (most defiled land) and extremely contaminated. Through the power of his kedushah and the trials he withstood and overcame, and by becoming ruler over the sar (angel) of Egypt, he weakened the power of tumah (impurity) and klipot (negative forces) at their root.

The holy Avot and Shevatim were the root of all Jewish souls throughout the generations, and whatever exists in the branch exists in the root. Therefore, through their holy actions, they opened a channel and prepared strength for all generations of Israel. This is the meaning of "to establish for you a remnant in the land and to sustain you for a great deliverance" - that Yosef HaTzaddik established a foundation and root of strength for all generations of Israel. This is the holy spark which is hidden within the nefesh (soul) of every Jew, inherited from our holy forefathers. We should understand why Chazal specifically used the term "yeshiva" to refer to a place of Torah, for just as there are those who sit in the Beis Midrash (study hall), there are also those who sit idly at street corners. The term "sitting" could apply to both, so what distinguishes one from the other? They should have specified "those who sit in the Beis Midrash."

However, it is clear that those who sit idly at street corners are not worthy of being called a "yeshiva" at all, because the term "yeshiva" indicates something that is eternal and endures forever. Only the holy Torah is eternal, and nothing else. This is similar to what King David requested (Psalms 61): "Let me dwell in Your tent forever," and our Sages explained (Yevamos 96b): "Is it possible for a person to dwell in two worlds? Rather, David said before the Holy One, Blessed be He: 'Master of the Universe, may it be Your will that they say teachings in my name in this world.' For Rabbi Yochanan said... any Torah scholar whose teachings are quoted in this world, his lips move in the grave."

Similarly, those who support Torah institutions and help raise generations of Jewish children in Torah - this activity has eternal existence. Only a Torah yeshiva is called a "yeshiva" in the essential sense, as our Sages said in the Mishnah (Avos 2:7): "The more sitting (learning), the more wisdom." This clarifies that the term "yeshiva" only applies to a place where Torah is disseminated.

Our forefather Yaakov and the holy tribes wanted to be completely separate from the Egyptians, and for this reason they settled in the land of Goshen. This is what they said to Pharaoh: "We have come to sojourn in the land" - meaning, in Egypt we are merely temporary residents - "Now, please let your servants dwell in the land of Goshen." This was to establish there a yeshiva and place for spreading Torah, which is eternal, and this was only possible in Goshen where they would be separate and distinct from the Egyptians. This is what the verse means when it says "And Israel dwelled... in the land of Goshen," indicating that they established there a yeshiva and house of study, as Rashi explains.

This explains the aforementioned Midrash "They said to him 'the peace' of all has been poured out." Meaning, the peace that you are alluding to regarding the Ten Martyrs (Asarah Harugei Malchut) is a peace of darkness and gloom and terrible decree. Yet the Ruach HaKodesh (Divine Spirit) calls out "Great peace have they who love Your Torah, and there is no stumbling block for them," because in the end they will have peace and the punishment will not actually befall them. Rather, their punishment will be cleansed through their being seized and their judgment being sealed, as stated in the aforementioned Pirkei Heichalot.

However, the Ruach HaKodesh was not revealed to them, because if it had been, they would not have experienced anguish at their judgment and their sin would not have been cleansed. Perhaps when Yehudah said "there is blindness here," he prophesied without knowing it - that even Yosef's words "and you shall go up in peace to your father," which alludes to the decree of the Ten Martyrs, is merely a blindness, to cleanse their punishment through the anguish of the decree without it actually being fulfilled, as mentioned above. But he did not fully grasp his own prophecy, so that they would not know of their salvation and their sin would be atoned through the anguish of the decree and through their having tasted the taste of death, as mentioned above.
